segments.Text:
This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 I am Alex.
This is Jason.
You will see that APT28 is crossed out.
That is because when we wrote this and when we submitted it, I was at FireEye, which tracks
this particular activity as APT28.
Now that I'm at CrowdStrike, I am used to tracking it as Fancy Bear.
And what we're here to talk about today is in the same vein of how attacks really are
complex events driven by human beings, as has been touched on by a number of talks so
far this morning, how misconceptions about what it means to be a human being and deal
with the human consequences of activities like the actors who are likely responsible
for Fancy Bear and things like that, specifically related to activity that has been documented
in recent U.S. government indictments over the last year, can help inform a variety
of both blue and red team activities.
All right.
So the normal disclaimers, and I have to actually read this word for word.
That's the policy, so I apologize.
We are here speaking for on behalf of no one but ourselves, and in no way do either of
us represent in any sort of way possible, at least any more, the United States government.
And our analysis is based entirely on assessments of open source reporting and our own experiences,
both together and separate, but generalized in a pretty understandable and obvious sort
of way as we go through this.
So we were given a very kind introduction, just to kind of go over it a little bit.
We tried to capture our own individual essences up here in one image each.
I spend most of my time tracking state nexus espionage.
I did it with a focus on critical infrastructure at FireEye.
I do it more kind of in what I find super interesting now that I'm at CrowdStrike.
Before that, I did a lot of critical infrastructure and cybersecurity exercise stuff for the U.S.
government, and I feel like this is a general good representation of what I look like on
a day-to-day basis at work.
And as was said in the introduction, I spent about 15 years in the U.S. intelligence community,
primarily designing, running, managing, executing offensive cyber and tech operations all over
the world.
Did that for, like I said, about 15 years, until about two years ago when I left, fled
the Washington, D.C. area to another part of the United States, and began working in
the private sector security, doing a lot of product stuff and managed detection and response
at a company called East Entire, where I am now.
In those 15 years, there were sort of two types of operations that I worked on, and
I only touch on this because it will become relevant as we get through.
One is what we would call remote operations, where everyone can do their job in shorts
and flip-flops from the comfort of their office, and at the end of the day, you get to go home
and hang out with your spouse and your dog and your cat, where you throw exploits at
a target, you get in, you spearfish people, you get that moment where you're like, we're
in, and everyone gets happy and people get awards and it's great and it's exciting.
But not all the time are those networks accessible remotely.
Sometimes you can't get in from 5,000 miles away and you have to get a little bit more
clever about it.
In those scenarios where we have things like close access operations, some poor schmuck
has got to wear a backpack and a disguise with a bunch of gear in that backpack and
wander around in a courtyard of an office building or outside the walls of a compound
and try to do something clever with the Wi-Fi or some other RF thing to try to bridge access
into a network for someone else to do something interesting with it.
And those sorts of operations, close access, have a unique nature about them, and we'll
talk about that as we get deeper on Fancy Bear.
So what we're here to talk about today is basically the fact that with a lot of state
nexus activity, we come with a lot of preconceived notions just kind of as a baseline community,
and certainly the general public does, as do a lot of the executives that we answer
to, especially if we're serving corporate clients, about how state nexus operations
come to be and what goes into making them and what you can kind of draw out of them
in observing them and responding to them.
And the reality is is that they're human, and like all human activities, there is chaos
involved.
Murphy's Law applies kind of across the board here, even though there's the preconceived
notion that if you're looking at a set of activity that has been attributed to a state
nexus actor, it's probably considered very sophisticated, but in reality there is a lot
more beneath the surface that is people scrambling to find solutions, people scrambling to meet
requirements, so on and so forth.
And so that's what we want to address here today.
And keep in mind, these actors, as sophisticated as they may be, at the end of the day what
they're trying to do is make sure that you don't catch them, or that even if you do catch
them, that you can't figure out who they are, and if you can figure out who they are, that
you can't do anything to really harm them.
Unlike criminal actors whose main goal is likely profit, make money, and then everything
else is sort of secondary to that, these actors' goal is to not get caught, other than some
weird corner cases where they want to get caught, but excluding those for a second,
for the most part they're spending lots of time, energy, money, resources, and people
hours to make sure that none of you in this room can either emulate what they do or detect
them when they're doing it.
So it's a very purposeful thing that they're trying to achieve, and because they're putting
that much energy and resourcing into doing that, they are often very effective at it,
and that drives a lot of the sort of analysis you end up doing on them.
So the way we're going to do that is primarily by looking at fancy bear activity, with a
little bit of sandworm activity as well, and I'm going to mention this again in a few
minutes, but to really concretely bound where the information that we're going to be
talking about comes from, there were two indictments issued by the United States
government against officers of Russian military intelligence, the GRU, that were issued over
the last year.
The first was issued in July of 2018, related to GRU activities aimed to interfere in the
2016 U.S. presidential election, and there was an October 2018 indictment targeting GRU
officers allegedly involved in remote and close access operations targeting a variety
of organizations, specifically those related to anti-doping efforts in international sport
and chemical weapons analysis, and so we're going to be really focusing within the bounds
of those data sets on activity that can be linked to fancy bear.
So why do we care, right?
So it's already been said, I think, no less than three times today that attribution is
important with an asterisk next to it, like it's important in general, but is it important
to you in your enterprise, at what level of attribution, or what level of attribution
is even relevant to you, right?
So what we're positing here is that there is value generically in attribution, knowing
who did a thing to you, or who's doing a thing out there in the wild, and that the more detail
you have about that attribution, the more better, excellent you can be in your day-to-day
activities, whether you're a blue team trying to detect those adversaries and what they're
doing, right, building a detection engineering regime that can detect the type of tactics,
tools, and techniques that those adversaries use, or if you're a red team, you're trying
to emulate the nature of how those adversaries behave so that you can better prepare your
enterprise for detecting them in the future were you to be targeted by them, or maybe
in some cases because you know you're being targeted by them through some particular means.
So one of the big things that when Jason and I were coming up with this talk was that there's,
like I said, there's this common conception that if you're dealing with state nexus activity,
particularly from, you know, specific states, you're looking at something that's sophisticated
and well thought out and well organized, and so there's this spectrum of highly orderly
entities and highly more so chaotic entities. You know, on one end we have there's the GRU's
coat of arms, and on the other hand we have the best open source image that I could find
of somebody I thought represented that end of the spectrum. And you imagine hacktivists
and criminals are on one end for the most part, and state actors, particularly intelligence
services, are on the other, with the idea that there's more opportunistic, there's more
opportunism on one end, more planning on the other, more reactionary activity on one end,
more proactivity on the other. But in reality, things are really messy, and I intentionally
made this slide messy and not pretty to look at to reflect the fact that there really is
everybody's on all ends of the spectrum. For example, when I was at FireEye, they put out
a blog about FIN7, and it was noted in some of the tweets and stuff that came out around
that that FIN7 has its own JIRA instance for operations that they maintained meticulously.
So there you have an e-crime actor definitely on the highly ordered end of the spectrum.
On the highly chaotic end of the spectrum from StateNexus, Joe brought up earlier that
in Crash Override they made not one but two mistakes, kind of at the very end of the attack.
So you can see that it's not, you can't fit these people into one end of a spectrum or
even in one box on a spectrum. It's, you have to be aware that with all of these actors
there's the potentiality for a variety of types of behavior and varying levels of chaotic
behavior within any given activity.
And no, look, to be fair, like this is really hard to conceptualize because it's very fluid
and it's dynamic and it changes every second of every day for every actor. The previous
version of the slide was really nice and easy to understand. That mental framework that
we have, it's not that way, and it's not necessarily a bad thing, but it's important to remember
that that's not always necessarily the case. In particular, we find that we have organizational
frameworks that even help drive that particular methodology. So, for example, the Pyramid
of Pain is a good example of this, where you have levels of sophistication in what can
be detected, right? You start at the very bottom where it's very basic and you work
your way up in a very serial way to the very top of the pyramid where it's really sophisticated
and really hard to detect or hard to change.
But that's a very formulaic and organized way to look at it, which makes sense in our
brains, but unfortunately doesn't really accurately represent the way the actors work. Instead,
they work a lot like this, where in some cases, one operation for a nation-state actor
might be all the way on the highly orderly side, but that same nation-state actor the
next day could be all the way on the highly chaotic side, but then most days of the week
they're sort of smack in the middle. They're running different operations with various
levels of complexity and chaos.
So what are the implications of this common misperception? So the key to remember is that
the chaotic nature of what's going on in that particular country's leadership and strategic
level organizations impacts everybody. And the way to think about this is that chaos
is like water, right? For those of you that have a basement or live in a wet climate,
water that starts off at the top, right, coming from the sky, tends to find its way down to
your basement one way or the other, right? And your basement floods.
Chaos is very much the same way. There's three levels where this operates. So one is the
strategic level, sort of the 100,000-foot level, where you have national-level leadership.
The next level down is sort of operational, where you have people making decisions about
what operations we're doing and how we're doing them. And that bottom-most layer is
the tactical, the people actually on keyboard, walking around the compounds with a backpack,
wearing a disguise, doing stupid things, the people actually executing those operations.
Those three levels get affected in a variety of different ways, depending on the nature
of that chaos and how much of it you see at the highest levels.
So that water can manifest in a couple of different ways, and I'm going to talk about
four of them. And the big ones are strategic culture, organizational culture, and kind
of the competition between organizations, which is sort of an evolution of sorts of
strategic culture. Leadership demands, which can vary significantly in how they impact
operations from one type of government to another. And then finally, domestic politics,
which often influences all of the other ones as well. And what all of this water does is,
you know, this idea that, oh, you know, the intelligence agency X decides that they need
to compromise target A, so they go out and plan the operation and just get to do it.
There's no simple conceive and execute plan when you're dealing with all of these different
variables affecting the way that you're trying to move forward.
So as I touched on before, the information in the case study that we're doing here is
very much based in information from open sources from U.S. government indictments. So I'm going
to slow down here for a second, because if I don't, what we're all about to say doesn't
make any sense. So there's two units that have been indicted, two GRU units that have
been indicted by the U.S. government, 26165 and 74455. Activity that was described in
U.S. indictments in 2018, in July of 2018, links 26165 to activity that has been publicly
attributed in blogs and in press reporting to APT28, also known as Fancy Bear. So by
that causality, you can look at unit 26165 and then draw a dotted line to activity associated
with them in an indictment in October of 2018, targeting anti-doping organizations and chemical
weapon organizations, and say that there is a reasonable way to make an assumption that
there could be a link between the Fancy Bear activity and unit 26165 in that context. In
the same extent, unit 74455 was charged in the July 2018 indictment as related to certain
influence aspects and other activities related to election interference in 2016. They were
also cited as being involved in certain influence activities related to targeting of anti-doping
organizations in the October 2018 indictment. Now, that's all on the one side. On the other
side, you have press reporting in the U.S. that linked unit 74455 to NotPetya, which has been
attributed basically by all and sundry to Sandworm. So from there, we can draw a dotted line
link for the purposes of this discussion to unit 74455. And for the same reason that Jason
read the original disclaimer word for word, I will read this word for word. Proceeding on
these explicit assumptions for the purposes of this talk, we'll operate under the premise that
discussed unit 26165 activity represents at least some segment of Fancy Bear activity, and
that discussed unit 74455 activity represents at least some segment of Sandworm activity.
Everyone got that? Cool? Welcome to my thesis. So getting back into how that water
manifests, what those chaotic dynamics manifest as, we'll start with strategic culture. This is
about as high up in influence as you can get. For a very simple version, Americans are known for
being very loud. In this case, studies of Russian intelligence operations throughout the ages
have given a picture of a specific culture that permeates the way that they conduct operations
that was termed by a former CIA official as the clandestine mentality. It's this idea dating all
the way back to the Bolshevik period that someone is out there to get me. The only way that I can
stop them is by engaging in secret counteraction. Therefore, I must always be engaging in action,
and I must always be on my toes, and must be emphasizing clandestinity in everything that I do,
which goes back to Jason's point that when typically in any intelligence service,
clandestinity is a major part of how they're operating. But here it goes to another level,
and that it is a pervasive element of the cultural approach to dealing with threats.
This manifests a little bit more clearly in organizational cultures, where you then have
the traditions of specific organizations, the histories of specific organizations,
impacting and mingling with that strategic culture to form an organizational culture.
In this case, the researcher Mark Gagliotti has talked about something called the wartime mindset
that he's described as evident in the Russian intelligence community since 2011. This mindset
consists of three major prongs. First is that Russia is at some sort of existential,
traditionally political and ideological existential risk, that that risk emanates
from the West, forcing Russia into a zero-sum competition with the West,
and that therefore action is always preferable over inaction to avoid loss of an advantage.
In the case of Unit 26165, you can actually see some of this in their unit motto, which is
there is always a solution. And with that impetus for action, that impetus for activity,
you're also dealing with competition dynamics between organizations within intelligence
communities. There is a rich, very volatile history of competition between Russian intelligence
entities, particularly between the Federal Security Service, the FSB, and the GRU,
known for burning each other's operations, outing each other's officers, stealing information from
each other. It can get very, very, very aggressive. Now look, I mean, Alex says this. Anytime he says
it and anytime a researcher talks about this competition between Russian intelligence services,
someone always wants to raise their hand and say, yeah, yeah, yeah, but the US has that too, right?
There's US intelligence services and they're competing and there's constricted resources
and all that sort of jazz. And the reality, of course, is that's true, right? There's always
competition between a nation-state's intelligence services and how they function with each other.
The difference, though, is that, at least from the United States perspective, that competition
occurs in a highly organized legal framework where it involves mostly lawyers and as much
as the individual operators and people involved want to flame each other and destroy each other,
at the end of the day, we're all on the same side. We're all working towards the same objectives
and we're all working together to achieve a common aim. That same sort of feeling, right,
that universal we're all out to do, that we're all in this together, one team, one fight,
is not pervasive if it exists at all within the Russian services.
So, I talked earlier about leadership demands. This is something that can be, it's a variable
that also depends on the type of government that a specific intelligence service is responding to.
In the US, for example, like Jason said, command authority goes through a lot of layers of structure
and legality and process before it reaches down to operational and tactical levels. While in a
place like Russia, you have power deeply concentrated in individuals as opposed to
in offices or in institutions. So, you have leadership demands that can manifest more
directly in operational activities. A good example in my view is the fact that you can look at a lot
of Russian cyber activity and see an element of Praetorianism in it. In this context, Praetorianism
refers to the idea that Putin has engaged in a series of demonstrable behaviors that aim to
delegitimize the ideas of democracy in Western political institutions as valid compared to the
political institutions that he has instituted in Russia. So, the idea is to delegitimize those
in the eyes particularly of a domestic audience in an effort to legitimize his own activities
and behaviors. There's a contrast here, of course, with the way this happens in the US.
There's a contrast here, of course, with the way this happens in the United States. Again,
to be fair, we don't want to pick on the Russians and say they do it and they're bad at it because
the Americans have a version of this as well. But again, the difference is it's a legal and
organized sort of way. We have a thing called the National Intelligence Priorities Framework,
the most boring administrative term you ever have, the NIPIF. The NIPIF is something that
the President and the National Security Council and the most senior levels of US national security
and foreign policy put together to say, what are the things we care about from a policy perspective
and we want more information on. So, when the President or the NSC says, I really care about
Peru and I care about Peru's economy. Well, someone then at the next level down says,
well, Peru's economy is based upon grain production and grain export. So, then as that
works its way down, what you end up with is that tactical operations executed by the US military,
the US intelligence community and other elements at the very like on the ground level, you can draw
dotted lines from those operations all the way up to the most senior levels of the government
because that NIPIF framework is what allows those lower levels to answer the questions that
the senior levels set out, right? Think about that in contrast to what Alex just explained here,
where its powers just concentrated entirely at the top and everyone's just trying to please
the master, right? Like that she but you knew there.
So, and then this is where domestic politics comes in. This is something that is more pervasive and
kind of more predictable than just related to leadership structures because every country
is going to have domestic politics no matter how liberal or conservative, for lack of a better
term, their government structures actually are. The case that we're looking at particularly,
I want to talk about the emphasis on targeting of anti-doping organizations. So, over the last
several years leading up to the Rio 2016 Olympics, there were a number of exposés and reports by
international sports administrative bodies that basically outed systematic Russian doping efforts
at major international sporting events. That's a loss of international prestige. It is not a loss
of international power. You're not losing control of territory or military assets. Nobody's getting
invaded. Your economy isn't being targeted, but your pride hurts and that can cause domestic
political costs. So, your national pride prestige can drive things which we like to call vanity
operations. You're engaging in operations specifically in order to recover some sense
of pride and prestige because you're feeling vain about the fact that you got caught doing
something wrong or that somebody outed something else you did. There's no other real edge to it.
Does anybody have a toddler at home? Because it's a lot like that, right? Like when you catch your
young child doing something wrong and they get upset about that, right, they tend to do something
else to either make up for it or actually make it much worse for themselves, which it's really hard
to convince them that they shouldn't do that. But it's the same sort of thing going on here,
it's a fascinating process. And it exists in both contexts. So, for example, in these operations
that Unit 26165 engaged in where they deployed close access teams to compromise networks of
multiple international anti-doping organizations, those materials were then exploited in influence
operations that tried to portray a general victimization narrative of Russia. Russia has
been victimized because they are persecuted for their superiority or that the West can't fairly
compete or that it's all political machinations at play and all the evidence is doctored. And you
can see in the indictment that actually lays out parallels between influence outlets operated by
Unit 74455 mirroring almost exactly the talking points of senior government Russian officials
in a relatively close time frame. And let's just talk about those close access operations for one
second, right? So, these are operations where intelligence officers are going overseas,
right, likely under some sort of cover with documentation to prove they are who they say
they are when they're actually not that person, right? So, they go overseas undercover with
documentation, they have technical gear that they use to execute these operations, right? They have
Wi-Fi gear, they have all sorts of interesting gizmos and gadgets like out of Inspector Gadget
or James Bond, all this sort of stuff squirreled away in their backpacks and hidden in secret
compartments. They have specially designed cars that they use to do this stuff, they have all
these tactics they use to avoid detection while they're walking around the city. All these things
happen when they get caught, it has a massive cost on the actor that just got caught, right? All this
stuff that they used is now exposed, they can't use it anymore, develop new tactics, people can't
travel, documents get burned, aliases get burned, all this bad stuff happens. And to do all of that
and risk all of that, Ford is essentially a vanity operation, seems utterly insane.
And again, we don't want to just talk about only Russia, there's a recent US example of this as
well. Back in November of 2018, there was a discussion about how US Cybercom conducted an
offensive operation, it was described in the press and also by US government officials targeting the
Internet Research Association. Agency. Agency, yes. I always confuse the two IRAs.
Where it became an issue where they were describing that they had disrupted the IRA
in engaging in what could have potentially been actions to influence the outcome of the US
elections in 2018. To a lot of people in the general public, this seemed like a big win. Oh,
the US is doing something against Russia, especially in our domestic political environment,
being able to, for the White House to be seen taking a hard stance against Russia is a politically
valuable point. But if you went one level down to security commentators, technology commentators,
from what was described, it sounded like maybe they turned off a LAN for a couple of hours.
And that's not a real effect in terms of the long scheme of things when you're conducting
nation state influence operations. If you have an outlet like the Internet Research Agency,
its main job is to build up narratives over a very long period of time,
insert those narratives into foreign political discourse, and then watch them create fractures
and fissures. How is turning off their LAN at the end of what would be their operational cycle
at all going to really impact something beyond scoring you domestic political points when it
reaches the press? This can manifest in a lot of different ways. It's not just one way or the other,
and it can even manifest at lower levels. National pride and prestige is one thing.
Being able to demonstrate taking other kinds of political stances is another.
So the actual genesis for this talk is this hang-on-tight thinking or methodology.
And there was something that happened a couple months back, and Alex and I were talking about
how crazy this thing was, and we started talking about this concept that the lower level officers,
the ones on the ground executing, the guys in the close access operations running around with the
backpack, they have this sense of hang-on-tight thinking because they're on a train that is
barely on the track. It is barreling down a track going very, very fast, extremely wobbly,
possibly going to go off the track at any minute, but they're just trying to hold on
while still doing their jobs because they have to do the things they're told to do.
Go execute the operations, get on keyboard, do the thing. They have to execute their job,
but they have to have this sense of what is actually happening and how does this influence
what I'm doing? And it influences it in a couple of ways. It influences it in the planning and
the timing of the plans that you're going to execute. Do you spend the amount of time you
really want to planning to the right extent the operations that you're going to run where
you don't want to get caught, where the calculus is really high? Do you spend the amount of time
you really want to in the execution of that operation to really make sure all the T's are
crossed, all the I's are dotted, all the things are done the right way to make sure that it goes
well and you don't get caught? In any of the post-op or follow-on activity, yes, it's done,
great, check the box, but that's it, right? Just move on to the next thing because we have so many
other things stacked up to do next. And then finally, in the aftermath of a compromise,
if you fail and you get caught and then potentially attributed, how do you respond to
that when you have this hang-on type thinking where I just got to do anything I can do to get
from one day to the next because everything above me is pure chaos, right? And I don't really know
what to do other than just keep doing my job to the best level that I can without getting myself
fired or in some cases killed. This impacts a lot of different things including operational
decisions. And a good example of this is where the operations manager goes into the room with
the management and says, I want to do this operation. I'm going to use a particular tool,
drunk koala. I want to deploy the drunk koala implant on this particular target. That's
fantastic, right? But then the management looks at that and says, well, we don't really want you
to do that. We want you to deploy a super short giraffe instead, right? But that's not the right
tool for the operation, but there's some political, some thing going on at some higher level that the
operator doesn't know about that impacts the way this decision gets made. And instead of using the
tool that's right for the operation, they end up being forced to use a tool that's not right for
the operation. This is a common outplay of what happens when you have that sort of chaos at those
higher levels. That chaos filters all its way down to the level at which I'm choosing what tools I
want to use in my particular operation. So now that we've laid out this whole structure of how
this chaos exists and what it can look like, let's talk about how it actually has manifested in our
case studies. So we have three here. The first, and I'll just go chronologically, we have the
Russian interference in the 2016 election. So this is the July 2018 indictment. This described
Unit 26165 as engaging in a sustained, very long, very persistent campaign to gain remote access to
a number of US political institutions and then distribute the materials stolen from that for
influence purposes. The biggest thing you see here is the targets, like the Democratic National
Committee, the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee, all of these things are high value
targets from an intelligence services perspective. If you get caught there, it's a big deal.
And so you had Fancy Bear, this is what the 26165 activity is really connected to per the indictment,
present in the DNC's networks for a big portion of 2016. But at the same time, it later came out
that there was a second bear in the DNC's networks, Cozy Bear, also referred to as APT29.
Now you would assume where you have the potential loss of clandestinity, the potential loss of tools,
the potential for attribution, the potential for loss of mission success, that there would be a
detailed, thorough structure to de-conflict operations in order to meet the goal associated
with sending a team to target those entities in the first place. Clearly, that didn't exist
because, as was also covered in press reporting and in blogs and all over Twitter, once Fancy Bear
got kicked out, Cozy Bear got kicked out too, and they had been there for longer. So it was
another operational dividend cost where potentially multiple intelligence services were losing
operations because they weren't de-conflicting. And that de-confliction is something that you see
formalized in a lot of other services, in a lot of other communities, and its absence here signals
that there must have clearly been some sort of impetus to cause two separate actor groups to
target the same entities in the same period of time while ignoring, essentially, the potential risks
involved. Then we go on to the GRU hacking to undermine anti-doping efforts. This ties back
into the discussion of vanity operations, domestic politics, and the really risks of close access
operations. There were numerous close access operations described in detail, and as somebody
who has studied this kind of activity for a long time, it was stunning for me to read an indictment
that laid out close access operations so thoroughly. I don't know the sources that
were able to procure in that indictment, but clearly those operations had been very thoroughly
burned. But again, you usually engage in close access operations when the remote options have
been exhausted, as Jason has described. The idea that they went all the way to the wall of choosing
close access operations on multiple occasions, reusing personnel, in some cases even reusing
laptops that still had information from old operations on them to target these entities
over and over again, signals again that the desire for a result was very, very, very high.
Despite the fact that there was a significant amount of risk involved, there was still the
decision to undertake operations using those tactics, techniques, and procedures.
I think it's important to note that the implication should not be that these actors
aren't sophisticated, that they reused the laptops with the same information on them,
the same tooling. That's not because they didn't know better. These are highly professional,
longstanding, they know what they're doing. These services are competent in what they're
out there to do, and they're good when they do it. So the fact that these compromises were made
for some reason, it lends credence to what Alex is saying here, that there's no foreseeable
operational reason why you would make those operational compromises when this is the logical
result. Not only do you get caught, but it exposes this operation, the way you did it,
the tools you used, the people involved, and historical operations that are then tied to it.
And then you have our last case here, which is the close access operations that were publicized
by the British and Dutch governments targeting entities related to chemical weapons analysis.
This material was released at the same time as the October 2018 indictments, but also included
a stunning, I feel stunning is the right word, PowerPoint deck describing in detail how a GRU
close access team was tracked and disrupted trying to target the organization for the
prevention of chemical weapons in The Hague. This is a kind of operation where it makes more sense
from a kind of grand scheme and even from like a tactical perspective to use a close access
operation to target a hardened entity that was related to ongoing political affairs that could
incur significant costs in terms of sanctions and diplomatic consequences for Russia in relationship
to the attempted assassination of Sergei Skripal in March of 2018. But you can draw a line from
the compromise of close access operations related to the anti-doping efforts to the compromise of
the operation against OPCW because some operators were reused, techniques were reused,
physical tech was reused. So by being willing to have to, not even by being willing, by having to
engage in high risk operational decisions in service of vanity objectives, you put future
objectives, future operations against real objectives at greater risk of loss of compromise,
loss of success, attribution, and so on. So why does all of this matter? We've been going on to
what could be a very really interesting master's thesis about the dynamics inside intelligence
organizations, which I know I'm prone and I know at least multiple people in this audience know
I'm prone to ramble on about. But at the same time, there is value in the holistic understanding of
what goes into adversary behavior. That is, if you're in a situation where these types of actors
are in your threat profile and there's something that you're confronting on a regular basis, or
even on a basis where they're going to be your edge case, but it's a very severe edge case,
a deeper comprehension of those drivers can help you defend smarter, emulate smarter, and overall
manage risk better. I spend a fair amount of time helping a variety of different types of
enterprises build a detection engineering regime. Not necessarily what tool in what place, but how
to think about what your threat actors do, how the nature of what they do affects what's going to
happen to your network, and then how do you build a system to detect those things, and then once you
detect them, which is only the first part of the battle, actually understand what that is and what
it means that you detected it in the first place. In the case of understanding not only who did the
operation at the attribution, but the nature of the actor who did it, how they think, how they apply
their methodology, and what they actually end up doing operationally helps you take the facets
that you learn that detection engineering and ideally spread it across your enterprise. So it's
not saying that I know that this particular actor has access to this particular exploit, therefore
I will make sure that my edge defenses are bounded and done in such a way to make sure I can protect
against that exploit, right? That's not a good strategic decision, that's a very tactical one.
How do you extract the value out of that attribution and understanding of your adversary
and spread the value across your detection regime? In addition, you can work to enhance the
fidelity of your emulation activities, and I liked in our keynote today where you talked about
not restricting your red team to say you are aptx and only do that, instead give them latitude,
right? Let them be the artist that they want to be in designing their red team behavior. As part of
that, let's expand it even wider, right? So for example, we can pen test and red team the
internal network all day long, but is anybody thinking about the fact that the Wi-Fi that you
use in your office is powerful enough, right? The APs you're using are powerful enough that that
Wi-Fi signal is seen at relatively decent strength three blocks down the road at a cafe where someone
could be sitting with a laptop and potentially interacting with your network unbeknownst to you,
right? There are these close access considerations where what is your adversary capable of and or
willing to do with it? How do you build that into those emulation activities? And at the same time,
even along the lines of threat hunting, which is a place where I often see a lot of interaction
between red and blue teamers and exchanging tactics in general where the discourse can be
strongest. If you're engaging in an operation as a red teamer or even as a blue teamer where
you're concerned about somebody like Fancy Bear, what kind of data is Fancy Bear going to be
looking for now that you're aware that they can be motivated by things like vanity, you know? It
could be valuable looking at an anti-doping institution, for example. There's multiple
data sets within an anti-doping institution that could be of value to the Russian government and
not necessarily all of them related to Russian or foreign athletes. A lot of it could be related to
relationships that those entities have to other international governance bodies. But if you know
XYZ current events could be driving particularly wounds of pride and prestige, it might be worth
simulating looking at where, you know, maybe there's been malicious activity here,
maybe it's worth simulating malicious activity here in those cases.
So where do we go from here? I was always a fan of presentations that got up and said a bunch of
things and then said, well, what's the next logical step from this, right? Not only what do you get
out of it, but what can we do from here? So one is what is the overall influence of government's
ideology all the way down to the execution of these technical and cyber operations? Well, we
talked about Russia a lot here. You can think of other actors where you apply the same methodology.
The Iranians are a potentially good example where in the sort of Iranian theocracy you have this
concept of exporting the revolution. Well, if you have that at the highest levels of the Iranian
government, if you bring that all the way down to the lower levels, how does exporting the
revolution and everything that that means apply in the intelligence operations context and in the
cyber operations context? In addition, how do pseudo and non-governmental interests also affect
these sorts of things? So for example, NGOs, think tanks, contractors, criminal organizations,
how do the way those organizations act and think and operate affect the way that these same
operations will be executed? And then how do you drive value from that into your own detection
regime? And on a broader basic level, you can basically take the academic function of
intelligence studies, which has gotten to be a stronger and broader part of the academic field
over the last couple of years, and start applying it to the internal dynamics of the relevant
entities. So a lot of times intelligence studies and histories of intelligence organizations focus
on big things. Counterintelligence failures, penetrations, historical deception operations,
wartime operations. But if you start looking in those resources and those research structures
and saying, let's take the lessons that we can learn about how an entity thinks, who that entity
responds to, what has typically been a big driver or not for that entity, and start applying it to
potential future cyber operations, you can glean a lot of the kinds of insights that we talked about
today. And with that, we intentionally left a few minutes so that we could answer any questions
you have. Thank you very much.
